s the best way to test that this has been achieved sucessfully?
Logically o=
r physically (implementation)?
Logically, you could do this by:
a) Validati=
on against DTD or Schema
b) asserting some XPath expressions

String compar=
isons of course won't do:
"<img xmlns=3D'http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml' src=
=3D'...' alt=3D'...'/>" and
'<html:img alt=3D"..." src=3D"..." xmlns:html=
=3D"http://www.w3.org/1999/xhtml"
></htmlimg>' are unequal Strings but equa=
l XML Elements.

String comparisons will only do if both the actual XML and=
 expected XML String
are canonical XML, and even then success is very limit=
ed:
- - The indention and other whitespace considered ignorable might still=
 differ
- - The contents of processing instructions and maybe even comments=
 that are
semantically identical might differ, e.g. <?xml-stylesheet type=
=3D"text/css"
href=3D"bla.css"?> vs. <?xml-stylesheet href=3D"bla.css" type=
=3D"text/css"?>

So, don't use String comparisons. I'm sure you already fig=
ured that out.

> Any input on this subject or a link to a page which gives=
 guidelines
> would be useful

There are several ways to achieve this.
When=
 I just do a series of XSLT, I usually don't do this using a Java program,
=
I use the xslt/style task of Ant. Then I use the XmlValidate task to valida=
te
both - source before the transformation and destination files after the
=
transformation. Of course this can be only achieved if asserting validity
a=
gainst a DTD (or, if you patch the XmlValidate Task, a Schema) is
sufficien=
t.

For more, you might want to take a look at:

* http://xmlunit.sourcefor=
ge.net/
This package provides an assertXMLEquals method that compares two s=
trings,
taking XML equality into account, so <br></br> and <br /> are consi=
dered
equal.

* http://httpunit.sourceforge.net/
This is more powerful, but=
 less XML-specific. It's especially then extremely
useful if you want to do=
 HTTP based tests.

* http://xsltunit.org/
A completely different approach =
not based on JUnit is this Unit testing
framework proof of concept for XSLT=
. I really like this approach.

Depending on the task you need to solve (on=
ly assert structure or also assert
contents), a combination might be useful=
.
Usually for XSLT specific stuff I use validation, a perl program for
gene=
rating a file list in XML and my own XSLT stylesheet which is taking that
f=
ile list and performing unit tests against all these files.

The biggest ad=
vantage of JUnit based unit testing is the brand report
generation using JU=
nitReport (automation is usually achieved with Ant
anyway).

Most powerful =
would be a set of methods like assertXPath, though there are
some stumbling=
 blocks:
- - One method for each XPath type or one for all of them?
- - The=
re's no official XPath Framework for Java yet (as far as I know), only
impl=
ementations, so either use DOM and be slightly incompatible with XPath,
or =
use XPath and settle on a specific library like Xerces/Xalan, depending on
=
all changes of that library.
